title: We Are Scientists
text:
{{short description|New York City-based indie rock band}} {{Use mdy dates |date=June 2013}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = We Are Scientists | image = We are Scientists.JPG | caption = Chris Cain and Keith Murray | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Berkeley, California]], United States | genre = [[Indie rock]], [[post-punk revival]], [[alternative rock]] | years_active = 1999–present | label = Masterswan, Devious Semantics, 100% Records, [[PIAS Recordings|PIAS]], [[EMI Records|EMI]], [[Virgin Records|Virgin]], [[Dine Alone Records|Dine Alone]], [[Dew Process]], [[Grönland Records|Grönland]] | website = {{URL|http://www.wearescientists.com/}} | current_members = Keith Murray
Chris Cain
Keith Carne | past_members = Scott Lamb
Michael Tapper
Andy Burrows }} '''We Are Scientists''' is a New York City-based [[rock music|rock]] band that formed in [[Berkeley, California]], in 1999.{{cite web |author=wearescientists.com |url= http://www.wearescientists.com/about/ |title=We Are Scientists Official Biography |publisher=wearescientists.com |year=2007 |access-date=October 28, 2009}} It consists primarily of guitarist and vocalist Keith Murray and bass guitarist Chris Cain, with drummer Keith Carne joining the band in the studio and for live performances since 2013.{{cite web |last1=Callwood |first1=Brett |title=We Are Scientists' Keith Murray On Margaritas and Megaplex |url=https://idobi.com/editorial/we-are-scientists-keith-murray-on-margarita-and-megaplex/ |website=Idobi |access-date=23 May 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200523132815/https://idobi.com/editorial/we-are-scientists-keith-murray-on-margarita-and-megaplex/ |archive-date=23 May 2020 |date=24 April 2018}} The band have released seven studio albums, not including their early release ''[[Safety, Fun, and Learning (In That Order)]]'', which the band have gone on to describe as more of a rough draft, than a proper album.{{cite web |last1=Chang |first1=Mary |title=Interview: We Are Scientists (Part 1) |url=https://theregoesthefear.com/2010/01/interview-we-are-scientists-part-1.php |website=There Goes The Fear |access-date=23 May 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007154840/http://www.theregoesthefear.com/2010/01/interview-we-are-scientists-part-1.php |archive-date=7 October 2011 |date=29 January 2010}} The band's breakthrough success came with their debut studio album, ''[[With Love and Squalor]],'' which sold [[Music recording sales certification|100,000]] copies in the first six months. This was followed by the releases of ''[[Brain Thrust Mastery]]'' in 2008, ''[[Barbara (We Are Scientists album)|Barbara]]'' in 2010, ''[[TV en Français]]'' in 2014, ''[[Helter Seltzer]]'' in 2016, ''[[Megaplex (album)|Megaplex]]'' in 2018 and ''[[Huffy (album)|Huffy]]'' in 2021. As well as music, Keith and Chris are known for their comedy, often injecting humour into their interviews, press-releases and off-the-cuff jokes at their live shows. This has been carried over as part of producing many of their own music video treatments and their 2009 series of television shorts ''Steve Wants His Money'' made for MTV,{{cite web |author=MTV |url= http://www.mtv.co.uk/shows/lil-mtv |title=Steve Wants His Money |publisher=MTV |date=October 25, 2009 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} as well as a podcast series titled ''Dumpster Dive'' in 2020.{{cite web |title=Our DUMPSTER DIVE podcast has lurched to life |url=https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?id=7643195379&story_fbid=10157938282825380 |website=Facebook |publisher=We Are Scientists |access-date=23 May 2020 |date=5 April 2020}} ==History== ===1999–2004: Formation and ''Safety, Fun, and Learning''=== Keith Murray and Chris Cain met in 1997 whilst attending [[Pomona College]] in [[Claremont, California]]. Keith had just transferred to Pomona and Chris was holding a [[Dawson's Creek]] viewing party and quickly bonded over a mutual love of stand-up comedy, film and television.{{cite web |last1=Barker |first1=Stuart |title=Interview: We Are Scientists |url=https://www.strongisland.co/2018/03/26/interview-we-are-scientists/ |website=Strong Island |access-date=26 May 2020 |date=26 March 2018}}{{cite web |title=Dumpster Dive: Mothra vs. We Are Scientists |url=https://podcasts.apple.com/gb/podcast/mothra-vs-we-are-scientists/id1505115097?i=1000472528851 |website=Podcasts (software) |access-date=23 May 2020 |date=24 April 2020}} In late 1999, after graduating and moving to [[Berkeley, California]], they hatched the idea for the band. Murray, Cain along with their roommate, Scott Lamb, who was also a fellow alum from Pomona College cofounded the group. Lamb originally played guitar and provided vocals, whilst Cain played bass and Murray played drums as well as handling vocals.{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists AMA |url= http://interviewly.com/i/we-are-scientists-jan-2014-reddit|website=[[Reddit]]/interviewly.com|publisher=interviewly.com |access-date=8 June 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150608140719/http://interviewly.com/i/we-are-scientists-jan-2014-reddit|archive-date=June 8, 2015 |date=January 2014}}{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2002/03/19/ |title=You Guys know Scott Lamb, right? Well he's back |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=March 19, 2002 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120222431/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2002/03/19/ |archive-date=November 20, 2008 }} The three of them chose the name We Are Scientists, after renting a truck from U-Haul. When they returned it, the inspector, after looking them up and down and assessing their wardrobe, asked if they were scientists.{{cite web |last1=Walsh |first1=Ben |title=We Are Scientists: The right chemistry |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/we-are-scientists-the-right-chemistry-6101792.html |website=The Independent |access-date=26 May 2020 |date=5 May 2006}}{{cite web |url= http://www.songfacts.com/blog/interviews/keith_murray_of_we_are_scientists/ |title=Keith Murray of We Are Scientists |last=Ortega |first=Shawna |date=October 22–23, 2008 |publisher=Songfacts |access-date=June 12, 2013}} Some publications later claimed their band name to be a reference to a [[Cap'n Jazz]] song of the same name, whilst others believing it to be a homage to the [[Guided by Voices]] track "I Am a Scientist", both of which the band have unequivocally denied.{{cite web |author=Contact Music |url= http://www.contactmusic.com/info/we_are_scientists |title=We Are Scientists Biography |publisher=[[Contactmusic.com]] |date=June 2008 |access-date=October 28, 2009}}{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2001/07/12/ |title=Move from Los Angeles to New York City |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=July 12, 2001 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011193035/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2001/07/12/ |archive-date=October 11, 2008 }} Touching on the subject in their Dumpster Dive podcast, Cain jested "I can say that pretty unequivocally that if we had known of Cap'n Jazz at the time of naming our band, we would not have named it We Are Scientists.". When it came to songwriting, Keith, Scott and Chris' were particularly influenced by films, comic books, with many of their earliest songs about fighting monsters.{{cite web |last1=Ryan |first1=Gary |title=Does Rock 'N' Roll Kill Braincells?! – Keith Murray, We Are Scientists |url=https://www.nme.com/music-interviews/does-rock-n-roll-kill-braincells-keith-murray-we-are-scientists-2578081 |website=NME |access-date=26 May 2020 |date=25 November 2019}} Keith and Chris moved to the [[Los Angeles]] area in late 2000, without Scott, recruiting Michael Tapper, whom they'd known during their time at Pomona, and who was in his last year at adjoining [[Harvey Mudd College]]. Michael would take drums over from Keith, who would now be the band's vocalist and guitarist, whilst Cain would continue playing bass. Moving again, the band relocated to [[Brooklyn]], New York in 2001 and began recording material in November, 2001.{{cite web |author=wearescientists.com |url= http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2001/05/ |title=We Are Scientists move to Brooklyn New York where they regularly performed at Luna Lounge on the Lower East Side of Manhattan |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=May 29, 2001 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080704172254/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2001/05/ |archive-date=July 4, 2008 }}{{cite web |author=wearescientists.com |url= http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2001/10/ |title=October 2001 News, Recording |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=October 1, 2001 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080704172606/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2001/10/ |archive-date=July 4, 2008 }} The band finished recording in January 2002, completing 12 tracks - two of which credit former member Scott Lamb.{{cite web |author=wearescientists.com |url= http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2002/01/ |title=Debut album recording complete News, Recording |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=January 24, 2002 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080704172406/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2002/01/ |archive-date=July 4, 2008 }} The releases title was announced on March 14, 2002, on the band's official website as ''[[Safety, Fun, and Learning (In That Order)]]'' for release in April 2002 through the band's own label, Devious Semantics. Due to issues with setting up their own label, it wasn't until June that the band were able to release the record.{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2002/03/14/ |title=Hello to you. From us. |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=March 14, 2002 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828042157/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2002/03/14/ |archive-date=August 28, 2008 }} The summer saw them reunite with original vocalist Scott Lamb.{{cite web |author=wearescientists.com |url= http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2002/06/ |title=News, Friday June 7, 2002 |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=June 7, 2002 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080704172222/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2002/06/ |archive-date=July 4, 2008 }} In October after several months of performing in [[California]] and New York, amongst other places the band recorded their first EP, available originally only at live shows ''Bitching!'' was released on October 14, 2002, and featured 6 tracks. Later ''Bitching!'' was made available online on January 16, 2003.{{cite web |author=wearescientists.com |url= http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2002/10/14/ |title=Bitching! EP |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=October 14, 2002 |access-date=October 28, 2009}}{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2003/01/16/ |title=Bitching! EP available online |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=January 16, 2003 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828042321/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2003/01/16/ |archive-date=August 28, 2008 }} In March 2003 the band announced they would be heading to the recording studio with Paolo DeGregorio on April 1 to record a second EP; [[In Action (EP)|In Action]],{{cite web |author=wearescientists.com |url= http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2003/10/16/ |title=In Action EP |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=October 16, 2003 |access-date=October 28, 2009}} which was released through MotherWest records in October 2003, featuring 6 tracks.{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2003/03/14/ |title=Children of the corn |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=March 14, 2003 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828042405/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2003/03/14/ |archive-date=August 28, 2008 }} A year after recording ''[[In Action (EP)|In Action]]'' the band headed once more to the recording studio with Los Angeles-based producer Chris Fudurich, where they recorded rough versions of "The Great Escape", "Scene Is Dead" and "This Means War", which would make up half of the band's final independently released EP The Wolf's Hour, other tracks included "Callbacks Under The Sea", "Inaction" and "Nobody Move, Nobody Gets Hurt". The EP was released on November 26, 2004.{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2004/04/19/ |title=You bashful, bashful others |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=April 19, 2004 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011193240/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2004/04/19/ |archive-date=October 11, 2008 }}{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2004/11/ |title=You iron-jawed romantics |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=November 26, 2004 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704171455/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2004/11/ |archive-date=July 4, 2008 }} ===2005–2006: ''With Love and Squalor'' and breakthrough success=== [[File:We Are Scientists Mainz.JPG|thumb|right|Keith Murray, Chris Cain and Michael Tapper performing live in 2006, Mainz, Germany.]] On January 11, 2005, the band began the recording of their first, proper full-length album in Los Angeles with Ariel Rechtshaid and engineering from Rob Brill.{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/01/11/ |title=Recording Day 1 |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=January 11, 2005 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011190230/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/01/11/ |archive-date=October 11, 2008 }} The band ended their time in the studio on February 23, throughout their time in the studio the band posted blogs on their official website, many of which told of a [[cat]] called Lewis, which would later be used on the album's artwork.{{cite web |author=wearescientists.com |url= http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/01/ |title=January 2005 |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=January 2005 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090526092216/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/01/ |archive-date=May 26, 2009 }} Having recorded the album, the band decided to sign to [[Virgin Records]] to handle to release.{{cite web|last1=Chase|first1=Ted |title=KEITH MURRAY OF WE ARE SCIENTISTS |url= http://www.qromag.com/interviews/keith-murray-of-we-are-scientists/ |website= www.qromag.com |access-date=8 June 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150608164207/http://www.qromag.com/interviews/keith-murray-of-we-are-scientists/|archive-date=June 8, 2015 |date=25 February 2014}} On May 15, 2005, the first single from the album was aired in the UK, "Nobody Move, Nobody Get Hurt", this came after a number of dates in the UK with [[Editors (band)|Editors]].{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/05/15/ |title=Nobody Move, Nobody Get Hurt UK Radio, music video |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=May 15, 2005 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011185959/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/05/15/ |archive-date=October 11, 2008 }} "Nobody Move, Nobody Get Hurt" was released later on June 27 at the same time as their own headline Summer 2005 UK tour.{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/05/11/ |title=Dear Membership, The UK |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=May 11, 2005 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061110052653/http://wearescientists.com/news/2005/05/11/ |archive-date=November 10, 2006 }}{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/06/ |title=June 27 single and UK dates |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=June 16, 2005 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120215611/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/06/ |archive-date=November 20, 2008 }} In July the band shot a music video for their second single, "The Great Escape", as well as appearing on [[MTV2]] for the first time to plug their upcoming release.{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/07/ |title=Video shot The Great Escape |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=July 9, 2005 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704172750/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/07/ |archive-date=July 4, 2008 }} The band also appeared on at [[Reading and Leeds Festivals]] for the first time, performing on the Carling Stage, and later the band released the album ''[[With Love and Squalor]]'' in the United Kingdom on October 17, 2005{{cite web |author=NME |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/21158 |title=Headline gigs for We Are Scientists |publisher=NME |date=October 5, 2005 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} celebrating with an album signing session and intimate gig in London's Selectdisc on Berwick Street.{{cite web |author=wearescientists.com |url= http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/09/ |title=Back from the UK |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=September 6, 2005 |access-date=October 28, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080704172126/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/09/ |archive-date=July 4, 2008 }}{{cite web |author=NME |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/21220 |title=Meet We Are Scientists |publisher=NME |date=January 24, 2006 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} In December 2005 the band made their U.S. [[Network television]] debut on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' where they performed "Nobody Move, Nobody Get Hurt", as well as announcing the release of their debut album, ''[[With Love and Squalor]]'' which would be released on January 10, 2006,{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/12/21/ |title=David Letterman, USA Release of With Love and Squalor |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=December 21, 2005 |access-date=October 29, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120215137/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2005/12/21/ |archive-date=November 20, 2008 }} although in January the band would be in the United Kingdom on the [[NME|NME Shockwaves Tour]] with [[Mystery Jets]], [[Arctic Monkeys]] and [[Maxïmo Park]],{{cite web |author=wearescientists.com |url= http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2006/01/24/ |title=NME Shockwaves Tour |publisher=wearescientists.com |date=January 24, 2006 |access-date=October 29, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080828042559/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2006/01/24/ |archive-date=August 28, 2008 }} before embarking on their own headline tour in April and releasing "Its a Hit" on February 20 and re-releasing "Nobody Move, Nobody Gets Hurt" on May 3.{{cite web |author=NME |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/22001 |title=We Are Scientists announce UK tour |work=NME |date=January 19, 2006 |access-date=October 29, 2009}}{{cite web |author=NME |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/22568 |title=We Are Scientists announce new single plans |publisher=NME |date=March 23, 2006 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} In September a co-headline tour across the US with [[Art Brut]] and a new split single with Art Brut covering W.A.S single "The Great Escape" and in-turn We Are Scientists covering Art Brut's "Bang Bang Rock & Roll".{{cite web |author=NME |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/24152 |title=We Are Scientists and Art Brut Split 7" completed |publisher=NME |date=August 30, 2006 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} With their ongoing success in the United Kingdom the band embarked on another full 15 date tour, with two nights at Brixton Academy in London due to demand,{{cite web |author=NME |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/23004 |title=We Are Scientists announce extra tour date |publisher=NME |date=May 8, 2006 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} it was on this tour that the band released ''[[Crap Attack]]'', a compilation album of B-sides and covers, as well as a [[DVD]] featuring music videos for all of the tracks on With Love and Squalor and live performances.{{cite web |author=NME |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/24739 |title=We Are Scientists to release new CD/DVD |publisher=NME |date=October 16, 2006 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} ===2007–2008: Departure of Michael Tapper and ''Brain Thrust Mastery''=== [[File:We Are Scientists 1.jpg|thumb|right|Keith and Chris after the departure of Tapper remained as the only two ''official members'' until Andy Burrows joined in 2009]] In January 2007 Murray announced that he had begun working on the band's follow-up to ''With Love and Squalor'' in [[Brooklyn]], New York,{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/25666 |title=We Are Scientists start work on new album |publisher=NME |date=January 5, 2007 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} previewing "Impatience" and "Spoken For" later that month.{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/25966 |title=We Are Scientists preview new album tracks |publisher=NME |date=January 22, 2007 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} During a UK tour that February they debuted the songs "Dinosaurs", "Chick Lit" and "Best Behavior".{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/26094 |title=We Are Scientists add UK dates |publisher=NME |date=January 29, 2007 |access-date=October 29, 2009}}{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/26719 |title=We Are Scientists debut new material |publisher=NME |date=February 27, 2007 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} Recording of the new album began on June 11 in [[California]] with Ariel Rechtshaid{{cite web |url= http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2007/07/ |title=Album finished |publisher=WA.S. |date=July 19, 2007 |access-date=October 29, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080704171830/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2007/07/ |archive-date=July 4, 2008 }} and ended on July 19.{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/28736 |title=We Are Scientists to play three secret shows |publisher=NME |date=June 4, 2007 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} That August the band made their second appearance at the [[Reading and Leeds Festivals]], performing on the [[BBC Radio 1|Radio One]] Stage.{{cite web |author=wearescientists.com |url= http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2007/06/04/ |title=You Rumpled Old Octopi |publisher=W.A.S |date=June 4, 2007 |access-date=October 29, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20081011191253/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2007/06/04/ |archive-date=October 11, 2008 }} September 2007 saw the band hire Max Hart as an additional guitarist and keyboard player for live performances.{{cite web|author=wearescientists.com |url=http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2007/09/18/ |title=Who is this Max Hart? |publisher=W.A.S |date=September 18, 2007 |access-date=October 29, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011191817/http://www.wearescientists.com/news/2007/09/18/ |archive-date=October 11, 2008 }} The addition of Hart was to fit the larger arrangements of new material. Days before the tour was due to start, drummer [[Michael Tapper]] quit the band.{{cite web |url= https://www.nme.com/news/music/we-are-scientists-40-1344448 |title=We Are Scientist drummer 'relinquishes his duties' |publisher=NME |date=November 1, 2007 |access-date=November 30, 2021}} [[Gary Powell (musician)|Gary Powell]] and Adam Aaronson took over from Tapper for the remainder of the tour.{{cite web |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/razorlight-38-1306378 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191220055727/https://www.nme.com/news/music/razorlight-38-1306378 |url-status=dead |archive-date=December 20, 2019 |title=Ex-Razorlight Drummer Joins We Are Scientists |publisher=Click Music |year=2009 |access-date=October 29, 2009 }} For eight of their November tour dates the band acted as their own support act, conducting "self-improvement seminars" under the name Brain Thrust Mastery.{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/32199 |title=We Are Scientists line-up strangest support act ever |publisher=NME |date=October 31, 2007 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} After Virgin merged in 2007, the band were now signed to [[EMI]]. Murray stated that the band had to deal with a lot of bureaucracy recording the new album, with EMI unhappy that they were working with producer Ariel Rechtshaid; who at the time was relatively unknown. EMI instead tried setting the band up with various "cheesy, cheesy, big producers who we didn't like at all". Ultimately, against their labels wishes the band did record with Rechtshaid and in March 2008 the band announced that ''[[Brain Thrust Mastery]]'' would also be the name of their new album. Garrett Ray handled drum duties for the album.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/brain-thrust-mastery-mw0000783625/credits |title=Brain Thrust Mastery - We Are Scientists | Credits |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |date=2008-03-17 |access-date=2016-07-23}} The first single from the record, "[[After Hours (We Are Scientists song)|After Hours]]", was to be released on March 3 in the UK. The album was previewed a week before its UK release on [[NME|NME.com]].{{cite web |author=NME |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/35031 |title=Listen to We Are Scientists' new album |publisher=NME |date=March 11, 2008 |access-date=October 29, 2009}}{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/34974 |title=We Are Scientists announce UK tour |publisher=NME |date=March 7, 2008 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} It came out in the United States on May 13.{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/35279 |title=We Are Scientists' new album gets US release |publisher=NME |date=March 18, 2008 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} "[[Chick Lit (We Are Scientists song)|Chick Lit]]" was released as the second single from ''Brain Thrust Mastery'' on June 9,{{cite web |url= http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/we-are-scientists/news/41638-we-are-scientists-new-single |title=We Are Scientists New Single |publisher=MTV |date=May 6, 2008 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} coinciding with performances at The Great Escape Festival,{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/36682 |title=We Are Scientists play secret afternoon barbeque gig |publisher=NME |date=May 17, 2008 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} Oxegen Festival{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/38106 |title=We Are Scientists sing for 'free beer' at Oxegen festival |publisher=NME |date=July 13, 2008 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} [[Glastonbury Festival 2008|Glastonbury Festival]], [[T in the Park]] and Reading and Leeds on the main stage,{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/39197 |title=We Are Scientists and 'special guest' cover Ace Of Bass at Reading Festival |publisher=NME |date=August 23, 2008 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} and a consequent North American tour in July.{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/36854 |title=We Are Scientists announce North American tour |publisher=NME |date=May 23, 2008 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} In the latter part of 2008 the band toured the US as support to [[Kings of Leon]] in the USA.{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/40877 |title=We Are Scientists on Obama win: 'It's like Christmas for adults' |publisher=NME |date=November 5, 2008 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} "Impatience" was the final single from the album, released on October 27. ===2009–2011: ''Steve Wants His Money'' TV shorts and ''Barbara''=== [[File:Andy Burrows 2012 a.jpg|thumb|right|Andy Burrows joined the band for the recording of Barbara and some of the subsequent live shows.]] In October 2009, Chris Cain and Keith Murray co-created a short television series for [[MTV]], titled ''Steve Wants His Money''. The series premiered on October 25, 2009, during the ''Lil MTV'' was created with MTV production company Ja Digital. The series focuses around We Are Scientists playing fictional versions of themselves, owing an American man, Steve, money and consequently running away to England where they attempt to sell off various marketing ideas to musicians, journalists, music DJs and promoters. The band had hoped to make a second series, however it ultimately did not materialise.[http://www.mtv.co.uk/shows/lil-mtv/episode/we-are-scientists-101-edith-bowman Lil' MTV › Episodes › We Are Scientists] mtv.co.uk, November 18, 2009[https://twitter.com/scientistbros/status/6209641436 C: ...that last night's episode of SWH$ was the *penultimate* -- not final -- episode. (We're 80% sure.)] Chris Cain on [[Twitter]], November 30, 2009 Having worked with a number of different drummers since Michael Tapper's departure in 2007, the band announced that [[Andy Burrows]] would be joining them for recording and touring. The band had originally intended on using a succession of drummers on their third album; however after Burrows left his band [[Razorlight]], he became their permanent drummer.{{cite web |url= http://www.nme.com/news/razorlight/46554 |title=Razorlight's Andy Burrows to record solo LP and join We Are Scientists |publisher=NME |date=December 5, 2008 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} In February 2010 they announced that their new record would be titled ''[[Barbara (We Are Scientists album)|Barbara]]'' and would be released on June 14, 2010. This would also be the first release through the band's own label, Master Swan Recordings, with distribution handled by [[PIAS Recordings]].{{cite web |url= http://www.gigwise.com/news/54545/We-Are-Scientists-To-Release-New-Album-In-June |title=We Are Scientists To Release New Album In June|last=Gregory|first=Jason |date=February 8, 2010|publisher=[[Gigwise.com]] |access-date=2010-02-09}} Burrows made his live debut with the band at a surprise [[NME]] awards show at [[London Borough of Camden|Camden]] Barfly on February 21, 2010.{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists to play Shockwaves NME Awards Show tonight (Feb 21) |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/49857|website=nme.com|publisher=NME |access-date=8 June 2015 |date=21 February 2010}} Demonstrating the more stripped-back guitar-centric sound of Barbara, the band were now performing predominately as a three-piece, without Max Hart, although Hart amongst other musicians would occasionally feature at live shows for performances of "After Hours". As Burrows was involved in a number of other projects, the band hired Danny Allen to perform and tour with them, with Allen occasionally handling keyboards at shows where Burrows was drumming. The band released their first single from Barbara on April 5, 2010, titled "[[Rules Don't Stop]]", which peaked at number 14 in the UK Singles Chart.{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists announce comeback single release |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/49630 |website=nme.com|publisher=[[NME]] |access-date=8 June 2015 |date=8 February 2010 }} A second single "[[Nice Guys (song)|Nice Guys]]" was released on June 7, the week before the release of album ''Barbara''.{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists announce summer shows and single plans |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/50934|website=nme.com|publisher=NME |access-date=8 June 2015 |date=4 May 2010}} The band would make appearances at a number of major festivals that summer, including [[T in the Park]], [[Glastonbury Festival]] and [[Reading and Leeds Festivals]]. Days after the album release on June 10, 2010, the band released their World Cup Anthem "Goal! England!" in support of the [[England national football team|England national team's]] campaign in the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]]. As well as releasing the single, the band launched their website for the song [https://web.archive.org/web/20100611061425/http://www.goalengland.co.uk/ goalengland.co.uk/], with videos of the recording.{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists record World Cup anthem for England |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/51433 |website= www.nme.com|publisher=NME |access-date=9 June 2015 |date=9 June 2010}}{{cite news |title=How To Write a World Cup Anthem |url=https://slate.com/culture/2010/06/we-are-scientists-the-band-behind-goal-england-explains-how-to-write-a-world-cup-anthem.html |access-date=25 May 2020 |agency=Slate |date=11 June 2010}} In August 2010, We Are Scientists and [[Ash (band)|Ash]] notably co-headlined two show in [[Australia]] as well as performing at [[Splendour in the Grass]] in [[Woodford, Queensland]]. At their two co-headline shows the bands came together to form ''WASH''; performing a number of covers together as an encore set.{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists and Ash interview each other |url= http://www.fasterlouder.com.au/features/24662/We-Are-Scientists-and-Ash-interview-each-other |website= www.fasterlouder.com|publisher=Faster Louder |access-date=8 June 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150608152342/http://www.fasterlouder.com.au/features/24662/We-Are-Scientists-and-Ash-interview-each-other|archive-date=June 8, 2015 |date=15 July 2010}} A year later the two bands came together again to release a cover of a track called "Washington Parks" by Robert Manning. The track was covered to help raise money for Multiple Sclerosis Society.{{cite web |title=Ash and We Are Scientists team up for charity song – audio |url= http://www.nme.com/news/ash--2/58574|website=nme.com|publisher=NME |access-date=8 June 2015 |date=11 August 2011}} The final single to be taken from ''Barbara'' was "I Don't Bite" which was released on October 11, 2010. ===2011–2014: ''Business Casual'' and ''TV en Français''=== [[File:14-06-08 RiP We Are Scientists Andy Burrows.JPG|thumb|right|Keith Carne joined the band as their live and studio drummer in 2013.]] A new album was first teased by the band at The Isle of Weight Festival 2011, where Murray suggested the band would be recording in Autumn that year.{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists confirm new album details at Isle Of Wight Festival |url= http://www.nme.com/news/we-are-scientists/57217|website=nme.com|publisher=NME |access-date=8 June 2015 |date=10 June 2011}} It was in 2012 that the band actually began recording new material, working with producer Chris Coady in [[New York City]], where both Keith Murray & Chris Cain reside.{{cite web |title=WE ARE SCIENTISTS ARE RECORDING 'THE BEST WE ARE SCIENTISTS SONGS EVER' |url= http://diymag.com/archive/we-are-scientists-recording-the-best-we-are-scientists-songs-ever |website= diymag.com|publisher=DIY Magazine |access-date=8 June 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150608161056/http://diymag.com/archive/we-are-scientists-recording-the-best-we-are-scientists-songs-ever|archive-date=June 8, 2015 |date=16 September 2012}} The band worked in a number of New York studios, predominately The Magic Shop, DNA Studio and Ash's home studio Atomic Heart. In December 2012 that drummer Andy Burrows confirmed that they had finished work on their new album, with intent to release in ''early 2013''.{{cite web|last1=Burrows|first1=Andy |title=back in lovely London |url= https://twitter.com/andywburrows/status/281701557953765376|website=Twitter.com|publisher=Twitter |access-date=8 June 2015 |date=20 December 2012|quote=back in lovely London. Listening to brand new @scientistbros album. It is our best. It's awesome. I am so excited about it. YESSS!!}} Due to the fact the band had recorded without a record label, and had also fired their management after ''Barbara'', the band then spent a lot of 2013 label shopping and looking for new management. Realising they would be unable to put the album out that year, the band released a two-track single featuring the songs "Something About You" and "Let Me Win". The single was released through their own record label Master Swan Records and [[Neon Gold Records]] on July 16.{{cite web |title=LISTEN: WE ARE SCIENTISTS' NEW TRACK 'SOMETHING ABOUT YOU' |url= http://www.gigwise.com/news/82854/listen-we-are-scientists-stream-new-track-something-about-you |website= www.gigwise.com|publisher=[[Gigwise]] |access-date=8 June 2015 |date=10 July 2013}} New material was further previewed across a string of UK tour dates in July.{{cite web |title=New U.K. Tour! July! Why Would We Lie?? |url= http://wearescientists.com/news/new-u-k-tour-july-why-would-we-lie/ |website= wearescientists.com|publisher=We Are Scientists |access-date=8 June 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150608170227/http://wearescientists.com/news/new-u-k-tour-july-why-would-we-lie/|archive-date=June 8, 2015 |date=23 April 2013}} Eventually the band signed to release the finished album with 100% Records, putting out a ''teaser'' EP titled ''[[Business Casual (EP)|Business Casual]]'' on October 14, 2013.{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists announce Business Casual EP, share "Return the Favor" |url= http://consequenceofsound.net/2013/09/we-are-scientists-announce-business-casual-ep-share-return-the-favor/ |website= consequenceofsound.net |access-date=8 June 2015 |date=18 September 2013}} The EP includes lead singles "Return the Favor" and "Dumb Luck" along with album off cut "Good Answer", a demo of new track "Courage" and a cover of [[Berlin (band)|Berlin]]'s "[[Take My Breath Away]]" - which features ''occasional scientist'' Max Hart on pedal-steel guitar.{{cite web |title=Song Premiere: We Are Scientists - "Take My Breath Away" |url= http://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/av/2013/10/song-premiere-we-are-scientists---take-my-breath-a.html |website= www.pastemagazine.com |access-date=8 June 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150608171302/http://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/av/2013/10/song-premiere-we-are-scientists---take-my-breath-a.html|archive-date=June 8, 2015 |date=10 October 2013}} Andy Burrows had recorded drums for the album and subsequent EP and singles, but by the time the band were eventually able to release and tour Burrows was busy with his solo-career. This led to Keith Carne taking over the majority of live commitments, with Burrows stepping in for occasional dates, depending on his availability. In January 2014, the band announced that the album would finally be released on March 3, 2014, through 100% Records and would be titled ''[[TV en Français]]''.{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists Announce New Album, 'TV en Francais' |url= http://diymag.com/archive/we-are-scientists-announce-new-album-tv-en-francais |website= diymag.com |access-date=8 June 2015 |date=13 January 2014}} Accompanying the album announcement was the music video for new single "Dumb Luck".{{cite web |title=Here's We Are Scientists Video For "Dumb Luck" |url= http://noisey.vice.com/en_au/blog/heres-we-are-scientists-video-for-dumb-luck |website= noisey.vice.com|publisher=Vice Magazine |access-date=8 June 2015 |date=13 January 2014}} Soon after the announcement the band revealed another new track titled "Make it Easy", which was made available to download to those who pre-ordered the album.{{cite web |title=Listen: We Are Scientists Unveil 'Make It Easy' Single |url= http://diymag.com/archive/listen-we-are-scientists-unveil-make-it-easy-single |website= diymag.com |access-date=8 June 2015 |date=30 January 2014}} On February 9, 2014, the band = We are scientists Rock im Park 2016 (8 von 5).jpg | alt3 = | caption3 = }} On February 5, 2018, the band released the single "One In, One Out". Two more singles from their sixth studio album, ''Megaplex'', were released: "Your Light Has Changed" on 15 March 2018 and "Heart is a Weapon on May 20, 2018.{{cite web |last1=Vigil |first1=Dom |title=We Are Scientists Release Video for "Your Light Has Changed" |url=https://preludepress.com/news/2018/3/19/we-are-scientists-release-video-for-your-light-has-changed/ |website=Prelude Press |access-date=24 May 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200524103105/https://preludepress.com/news/2018/3/19/we-are-scientists-release-video-for-your-light-has-changed/ |archive-date=24 May 2020 |date=18 March 2018}} Touring the United Kingdom in promotion of the record took place across March, April and May 2018.{{cite web |last1=Trendell |first1=Andrew |title=We Are Scientists unveil new single 'One In One Out', announce UK tour and new album 'Megaplex' |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/scientists-unveil-new-single-one-one-announce-uk-tour-new-album-megaplex-2236448 |website=NME |access-date=24 May 2020 |date=5 February 2018}} Keith and Chris wrote the majority of the album's tracks in sessions for a songwriting club called 'Song Challenge', with Cain describing it as a collective who compete to each write 10 songs in 8 hours and drink beer. ''Megaplex'' was once again produced by ''Occasional Scientist'' Max Heart, and recorded across various sessions in 2017 in New York City.{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists about "Megaplex", Ball-Music and Fruit-Leather |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=crDE8fABTK0 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/crDE8fABTK0 |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|website=Youtube |access-date=24 May 2020 |date=9 May 2018}}{{cbignore}}{{cite web|last1=McAllister|first1=Clair|title=INTERVIEW: Chris Cain of WE ARE SCIENTISTS discusses new album + Limelight, Belfast gig|url=http://www.xsnoize.com/interview-chris-cain-of-we-are-scientists-discusses-new-album-limelight-belfast-gig/|website=XS NOIZE|access-date=25 May 2018|date=15 March 2018}} On February 15, 2019, the band released "Second Acts". |url=https://www.upsetmagazine.com/news/we-are-scientists-are-celebrating-their-50th-anniversary-with-with-love-and-squalor-live-in-woodstock-1969 |website=Upset Magazine |access-date=24 May 2020 |url=https://www.nme.com/music-interviews/we-are-scientists-look-back-on-with-love-squalor-its-been-a-rollercoaster-ride-in-that-weve-been-throwing-up-a-lot-2584063 |website=NME |access-date=24 May 2020 |date=6 April 2019}} In March 2020, as lockdown began for the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], the band started a podcast series centred around dissecting their old material, but often spiralling out into random topics, called the ''Dumpster Dive''. During the first months of lockdown, the band also put out regular live streams on Instagram, featuring them discussing all manner of topics and performing their tracks. On May 21, 2020, We Are Scientists appeared on Jo Whiley's [[BBC Radio 2]] show, premiering their new single "I Cut My Own Hair".{{cite web |last1=Whiley |first1=Jo |title=We Are Scientists and Emma Bullimore |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/m000j9gt |website=BBC Radio 2 |access-date=25 May 2020 |date=21 May 2020}} While the song was written long before the COVID-19 pandemic, the idea of many people resorting to cutting their own hair made the band feel that the song had a new, different resonance and decided it was a fitting time to release the single.{{cite web |last1=Kelly |first1=Emma |title=We Are Scientists: 'An upside of the pandemic is the much lower bar for acceptable hairstyles' |url=https://metro.co.uk/2020/05/26/are-scientists-upside-pandemic-much-lower-bar-acceptable-hairstyles-12758989/ |website=Metro |access-date=26 May 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200526135516/https://metro.co.uk/2020/05/26/are-scientists-upside-pandemic-much-lower-bar-acceptable-hairstyles-12758989/ |archive-date=26 May 2020 |date=26 May 2020}}{{cite web |last1=Moore |first1=Sam |title=Watch We Are Scientists give themselves DIY haircuts in 'I Cut My Own Hair' video |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/we-are-scientists-i-cut-my-own-hair-video-diy-haricuts-2674060 |website=NME |access-date=23 May 2020 |date=22 May 2020}} On May 22, they made "I Cut My Own Hair" available to stream and download, as well as releasing some merchandise to accompany the single. The track was also released in conjunction with the ''Big Buzz Off'' campaign, part of Mental Health Awareness Week 2020 for the charity [[Campaign Against Living Miserably]].{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists are very keen you do something about your hair |url=https://www.readdork.com/news/we-are-scientists-cut-my-own-hair |website=Dork |access-date=23 May 2020 |date=22 May 2020}} In July 2021 the band announced their seventh studio album ''[[Huffy (album)|Huffy]]'' would be released on October 8, 2021 through 100% Records.{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists announce new album ‘Huffy’ with loved-up single ‘Contact High’ |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/we-are-scientists-new-album-huffy-single-contact-high-listen-2983033 |website=NME |date=1 July 2021}} The announcement also included their new single "Contact High" and detailed their plans to tour the United Kingdom in November through December then and Europe in April 2022.{{cite web |title=WE ARE SCIENTISTS ANNOUNCE 2021 UK TOUR |url=https://diymag.com/2021/07/05/we-are-scientists-2021-uk-tour-huffy-album |website=DIY Magazine |date=5 July 2021}} The band released another single, "Sentimental Education" on October 6, 2021.{{cite web |title=WE ARE SCIENTISTS REVEAL NEW SINGLE ‘SENTIMENTAL EDUCATION’ |url=https://diymag.com/2021/10/06/we-are-scientists-new-sentimental-education |website=DIY Magazine |date=6 October 2021}} Across 2022 the band performed at a number of festivals, including Into the Wild, [[Y Not Festival]] and Victorious Festival.{{cite web |title=THE KOOKS, KELIS, WE ARE SCIENTISTS AND MORE JOIN Y NOT FESTIVAL LINEUP |url=https://diymag.com/2022/02/22/the-kooks-kelis-we-are-scientists-y-not-festival-2022 |website=DIY Magazine |date=22 February 2022}}{{cite web |title=Stereophonics, Declan McKenna, Self Esteem and more for Victorious Festival 2022 |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/stereophonics-declan-mckenna-self-esteem-and-more-for-victorious-festival-2022-3116252 |website=NME |date=10 December 2021}} ===2022-present: "Operator Error"=== On September 21, 2022 the band released their new single "Operator Error".{{cite web |title=We Are Scientists share punchy new single ‘Operator Error’ |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/we-are-scientists-share-punchy-new-single-operator-error-3315234 |website=NME |date=22 September 2022}} ==Style and performance== [[File:We Are Scientists, Boileroom, Guildford (30295787791).jpg|thumb|right|We Are Scientists performing in Guildford, United Kingdom in 2016.]] Before their debut album, their earliest material often drew inspiration for lyrics from comic books and films, whilst the music drew from more punk influences. Keith Murray has cited the influence of such performers as [[The Rapture (band)|The Rapture]] and [[David Bowie]] on their debut album. The band has noted that tracks on ''With Love and Squalor'' were largely written to be performed live, whilst ''Brain Thrust Mastery'' was a more specifically studio effort.{{cite web |author=Peterborough Today |url= http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/localbands/Interview-Keith-Murray-from-We.3484279.jp |title=Interview: Keith Murray |publisher=Peterborough Today |date=November 14, 2007 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} Older influences include [[Brian Eno]], [[Velvet Underground]], [[My Bloody Valentine (band)|My Bloody Valentine]] and David Bowie's [[David Bowie#1976–1979: Berlin era|Berlin era]] as well as [[Hall & Oates]] and [[Fleetwood Mac]]. Murray and Cain are known for incorporating comedy into their live performances, music videos and when giving interviews.{{cite web |url= http://wearescientists.com/sci-cave/ |title=We Are Scientists presents… |publisher=Wearescientists.com |access-date=2011-07-04}}{{cite web |author=NME |url= http://www.nme.com/reviews/we-are-scientists/7922 |title=We Are Scientists: The Pyramids Centre, Portsmouth: Wednesday April 5 |publisher=NME |date=April 21, 2008 |access-date=October 29, 2009}} British magazine God Is In The TV put forward that Keith Murray and Chris Cain demonstrated "sarcasm and wit not normally found coming from two of our American cousins", going on to put forward that this may have been lost in translation when the band first emerged to prominence in 2005.{{cite web |last1=Auton |first1=James |title=WE ARE SCIENTISTS – ROUNDHOUSE, LONDON – 07/12/2019 |url=http://www.godisinthetvzine.co.uk/2019/12/10/we-are-scientists-roundhouse-london-7-12-19/ |website=God Is In The TV |access-date=26 May 2020 |date=10 December 2019}} Writing for [[The Independent]], Ben Walsh wrote "they are incorrigible wags, who are refreshingly willing to riff on any given topic". Their live and interview "banter" is always [[Improvisation|off-the-cuff]], with Murray insisting that the thought of ever rehearsing or reusing material makes him "cringe". The band come up with the majority of their music video concepts themselves. Earlier in the band's career the band frequently collaborated on music videos and other video content with [[Akiva Schaffer]] of [[The Lonely Island]].{{cite web |last1=Ready |first1=Alice |title=Interview – We Are Scientists |url=https://www.concrete-online.co.uk/we-are-scientists-interview/ |website=Concrete Online |access-date=24 May 2020 |date=28 March 2014}}{{cite episode| title=December 5, 2008 | series= [[Soccer AM]] | network =[[Sky Sports]] | season = 1 }} ==Members== Since the departure of Michael Tapper in 2007, We Are Scientists has primarily consisted of Murray and Cain. Drummer Keith Carne has featured since 2013 in the studio, at live shows and in promotions such as music videos. Murray has stated that he and Cain "really consider him a part of the band", going on to joke that "it's the two of us, and then our drummer Keith Carne. That’s the real issue — having another Keith in the band. Too many Keiths." "Honorary Scientist" Max Hart performed guitars and keyboards with the band during their ''Brian Thrust Mastery'' era, and has sporadically featured at live shows since then as well as producing their albums ''Helter Seltzer'' and ''Megaplex''. {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ;Current members *Keith Murray – [[vocals|lead vocals]], [[guitar]]s, [[Keyboard (instrument)|keyboards]] (1999–present), drums (1999) *Chris Cain – [[bass guitar|bass]], [[backing vocals]] (1999–present) ;Current touring members *Keith Carne – [[drums]], [[percussion]] (2013–present) {{col-2}} ;Former members *Scott Lamb – guitar (1999; touring member 2002), lead vocals (1999), backing vocals, keyboards (2002) *Michael Tapper – drums, percussion, backing vocals (2000–2007) *[[Andy Burrows]] – [[drums]], [[percussion]], [[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]], backing vocals (2009–2014) ;Former touring members *Danny Allen - keyboards, drums (2009–2012) *Max Hart - guitar, backing vocals, keyboards (2008–2010, 2013) *Adam Aaronson - drums (2007–2009) {{col-end}} ===Timeline===
